hints_html:
To solve for \(\displaystyle f'(x)\), use the chain rule and the product rule on the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\end{aligned}\]

You will find an equation for \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) that still depends on \(\displaystyle f(x)\). To express \(\displaystyle f(x)\) with respect to x only, use

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\end{aligned}\]

a second time.
hints_latex:
You will find an equation for $\displaystyle f'(x)$ that still depends
on $\displaystyle f(x)$. To express $\displaystyle f(x)$ with respect to
\emph{x} only, use

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)
\end{align*}

a second time.
hints_raw:
To solve for <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math>, use the chain rule and the product rule on the equation

:<math> \displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)
</math>
You will find an equation for <math>\displaystyle f'(x) </math> that still depends on <math> \displaystyle f(x) </math>. To express <math> \displaystyle f(x) </math> with respect to ''x'' only, use

:<math> \displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)
</math>

a second time.
question: C 01
sols_html:
First we will solve for \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) using the chain rule on the left and the product rule on the right.

\(\frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x) = \ln(x) + x \frac1x\)

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)f(x)\)

In order to complete the question, we must solve for \(f(x)\) in terms of x. We will do this by using the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\end{aligned}\]

a second time, together with the log rule \(a \ln(b) = \ln(b^a)\). So we can rewrite the right side of the the equation above as:

\(\displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = \ln(x^x)\)

Applying the exponential function to both sides causes the logarithm to disappear, leaving:

\(e^{\ln(f(x))} = e^{\ln(x^x)}\)

\(\displaystyle f(x) = x^x\)

Substituting this into our derivative, we arrive at the final answer:

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)(x^x)\)
sols_latex:
First we will solve for $\displaystyle f'(x)$ using the chain rule on
the left and the product rule on the right.

$\frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x) = \ln(x) + x \frac1x$

$\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)f(x)$

In order to complete the question, we must solve for $f(x)$ in terms of
\emph{x}. We will do this by using the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)
\end{align*}

a second time, together with the log rule $a \ln(b) = \ln(b^a)$. So we
can rewrite the right side of the the equation above as:

$\displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = \ln(x^x)$

Applying the exponential function to both sides causes the logarithm to
disappear, leaving:

$e^{\ln(f(x))} = e^{\ln(x^x)}$

$\displaystyle f(x) = x^x$

Substituting this into our derivative, we arrive at the final answer:

$\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)(x^x)$
sols_raw:
First we will solve for <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math> using the chain rule on the left and the product rule on the right.  

<math>\frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x) = \ln(x) + x \frac1x</math>

<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)f(x)</math>

In order to complete the question, we must solve for <math>f(x)</math> in terms of ''x''.  We will do this by using the equation

:<math> \displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)
</math>

a second time, together with the log rule <math>a \ln(b) = \ln(b^a)</math>.  So we can rewrite the right side of the the equation above as:

<math>\displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = \ln(x^x)</math>

Applying the exponential function to both sides causes the logarithm to disappear, leaving:

<math>e^{\ln(f(x))} = e^{\ln(x^x)}</math>

<math>\displaystyle f(x) = x^x</math>

Substituting this into our derivative, we arrive at the final answer:

<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)(x^x)</math>
statement_html: Suppose \(f\)(x) satisfies the equation ln(\(f\)(x)) = x ln(x). Express \(f\)’(x) in terms of x only (i.e. do not leave \(f\)(x) in the expression).
statement_latex:
Suppose \emph{$f$(x)} satisfies the equation \emph{ln($f$(x)) = x ln(x)}.
Express \emph{$f$'(x)} in terms of \emph{x} only (i.e. do not leave
\emph{$f$(x)} in the expression).
statement_raw: Suppose ''&fnof;(x)'' satisfies the equation ''ln(&fnof;(x)) = x ln(x)''. Express ''&fnof;'(x)'' in terms of ''x'' only (i.e. do not leave ''&fnof;(x)'' in the expression).
